<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 194, 218, 207]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 215, 388, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 1 (S1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 321, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 352, 827, 432]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet. Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 283, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 905, 508]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 509, 605, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 606, 554]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 555, 755, 570]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 571, 440, 585]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 587, 905, 617]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The ages, \(x\) years, of 150 cars are summarised by \(\Sigma x = 645\) and \(\Sigma x^2 = 8287.5\). Find \(\Sigma (x - \bar{x})^2\), where \(\bar{x}\) denotes the mean of \(x\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 89, 920, 107]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 136, 96, 154]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 707, 153]]<|/det|> The random variable \(X\) has the probability distribution shown in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 163, 665, 210]]<|/det|>
\(x\)246
P(\(X = x\))0.50.40.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 223, 920, 270]]<|/det|> Two independent values of \(X\) are chosen at random. The random variable \(Y\) takes the value 0 if the two values of \(X\) are the same. Otherwise the value of \(Y\) is the larger value of \(X\) minus the smaller value of \(X\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 285, 154, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 285, 542, 303]]<|/det|> Draw up the probability distribution table for \(Y\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 316, 154, 333]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 316, 395, 333]]<|/det|> Find the expected value of \(Y\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 316, 920, 333]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 362, 96, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 362, 920, 411]]<|/det|> In Restaurant Bijoux \(13\%\) of customers rated the food as ‘poor’, \(22\%\) of customers rated the food as ‘satisfactory’ and \(65\%\) rated it as ‘good’. A random sample of 12 customers who went for a meal at Restaurant Bijoux was taken. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 425, 154, 443]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 425, 920, 443]]<|/det|> Find the probability that more than 2 and fewer than 12 of them rated the food as ‘good’. [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 457, 920, 488]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 920, 122]]<|/det|> An English examination consists of 8 questions in Part \(A\) and 3 questions in Part \(B\). Candidates must choose 6 questions. The order in which questions are chosen does not matter. Find the number of ways in which the 6 questions can be chosen in each of the following cases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 154, 152]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 135, 635, 151]]<|/det|> There are no restrictions on which questions can be chosen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 152]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 164, 156, 181]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 164, 611, 180]]<|/det|> Candidates must choose at least 4 questions from Part \(A\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 164, 920, 182]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 193, 154, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 193, 920, 225]]<|/det|> Candidates must either choose both question 1 and question 2 in Part \(A\), or choose neither of these questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 209, 920, 227]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 250, 94, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 250, 920, 297]]<|/det|> A box of biscuits contains 30 biscuits, some of which are wrapped in gold foil and some of which are unwrapped. Some of the biscuits are chocolate-covered. 12 biscuits are wrapped in gold foil, and of these biscuits, 7 are chocolate-covered. There are 17 chocolate-covered biscuits in total. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 310, 156, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 310, 828, 326]]<|/det|> Copy and complete the table below to show the number of biscuits in each category. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 310, 920, 327]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 335, 898, 432]]<|/det|>

Not chocolate-covered
